fields.description:
Reported by NSA:

  
Eucalyptus uses improper permissions on the directories that contain the
images of a live instance. In both Eucalyptus 1.6 and 2.0, the following
directories are world readable:

1. /var/lib/eucalyptus/instances/<instance-id> on NC

2. /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits on Walrus

  
If a malicious attacker gained control of any account on the NC, they would be
able to read the current disk image of any instance that is currently being
run on NC. Since the bukkits folder on the Walrus is world readable, any files
put there can be read by any user on the Walrus box.
fields.summary: improper permissions on the directories that contain the images of live instances

comments.body:
Originally posted on 2011-05-09 20:27:02

Mon May 09 13:27:01 2011: Request 2158 was acted upon.
 Transaction: Ticket created by vika.felmetsger
       Queue: Engineering Bugs
     Subject: improper permissions on the directories that contain the images
 of live instances
       Owner: Nobody
  Requestors: Vika.Felmetsger@eucalyptus.com
      Status: new
 Ticket <URL: http://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=2158 >


 Reported by NSA:

Eucalyptus uses improper permissions on the directories that contain the images
of a live instance. In both Eucalyptus 1.6 and 2.0, the following directories
are world readable:
1. /var/lib/eucalyptus/instances/<instance-id> on NC
2. /var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits on Walrus

If a malicious attacker gained control of any account on the NC, they would be
able to read the current disk image of any instance that is currently being run
on NC. Since the bukkits folder on the Walrus is world readable, any files put
there can be read by any user on the Walrus box.

Originally posted on 2011-05-26 21:06:52

Thu May 26 14:06:52 2011: Request 2158 was acted upon.
 Transaction: Given to dmitrii.zagorodnov by vika.felmetsger
       Queue: Engineering Bugs
     Subject: improper permissions on the directories that contain the images of live instances
       Owner: dmitrii.zagorodnov
  Requestors: Vika.Felmetsger@eucalyptus.com
      Status: new
 Ticket <URL: http://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=2158 >


This transaction appears to have no content

Originally posted on 2011-05-26 21:19:33
permissions on bukkits directory are not tracked through ticket #2341

http://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=2158 This is a comment.
It is not sent to the Requestor(s): permissions on bukkits directory are not
tracked through ticket #2341

Originally posted on 2011-05-26 21:26:47

tracked" ;) On Thu May 26 14:19:33 2011, vika.felmetsger wrote: > permissions
on bukkits directory are not tracked through ticket #2341

Originally posted on 2011-05-26 21:27:42 by dmitrii
In the new, blobstore-based NC, directories have world-executable bit set:

  

drwxrwx--x 2 eucalyptus eucalyptus 4096 2011-05-21 17:16 eki-BA12143C-2a80700d

drwxrwx--x 2 eucalyptus eucalyptus 4096 2011-05-21 17:18 emi-21A4125A-0a65ff09

drwxrwx--x 2 eucalyptus eucalyptus 4096 2011-05-21 17:17 eri-239E15D8-238c9393

drwxrwx--x 2 eucalyptus eucalyptus 4096 2011-05-21 17:18 prt-00512swap-
ac8d5670

  
While the files in those directories are not accessible to the world:

  

-rw-r----- 1 eucalyptus eucalyptus 16777216 2011-05-21 17:05 blocks

-rw-rw---- 1 eucalyptus eucalyptus  0 2011-05-21 17:18 refs

-rw-rw---- 1 eucalyptus eucalyptus  3484 2011-05-21 17:05 sig  
  
If the directories are not world-executable, KVM is unable to boot VMs,
probably because 'kvm' processes run as user other than 'eucalyptus'. Simply
adding the qemu/kvm user to group 'eucalyptus' was not sufficient. This can
probably be resolved in a better way, but this matter requires further
investigation, with the ultimate solution tested on all distros and with
proper documentation. The current solution appears to be reasonably secure and
is more likely to work across distros as is.

Originally posted on 2011-05-26 21:27:43 by dmitrii
According to our records, your request has been resolved. If you have any
further questions or concerns, please respond to this message.

It is not sent to the Requestor(s): In the new, blobstore-based NC,
directories have world-executable bit set: drwxrwx--x 2 eucalyptus eucalyptus
4096 2011-05-21 17:16 eki-BA12143C-2a80700ddrwxrwx--x 2 eucalyptus eucalyptus
4096 2011-05-21 17:18 emi-21A4125A-0a65ff09drwxrwx--x 2 eucalyptus eucalyptus
4096 2011-05-21 17:17 eri-239E15D8-238c9393drwxrwx--x 2 eucalyptus eucalyptus
4096 2011-05-21 17:18 prt-00512swap-ac8d5670 While the files in those
directories are not accessible to the world: -rw-r----- 1 eucalyptus
eucalyptus 16777216 2011-05-21 17:05 blocks-rw-rw---- 1 eucalyptus eucalyptus
0 2011-05-21 17:18 refs-rw-rw---- 1 eucalyptus eucalyptus 3484 2011-05-21
17:05 sig If the directories are not world-executable, KVM is unable to boot
VMs, probably because 'kvm' processes run as user other than 'eucalyptus'.
Simply adding the qemu/kvm user to group 'eucalyptus' was not sufficient. This
can probably be resolved in a better way, but this matter requires further
investigation, with the ultimate solution tested on all distros and with
proper documentation. The current solution appears to be reasonably secure and
is more likely to work across distros as is.

We need to evaluate if information in these files is security-critical and, if
so fix their permissions as well.
